Graphical abstract In this paper, a kaolin-based NaY-type zeolite crystal (KL-NY) material with large specific surface area and pore volume was prepared through in-situ crystallization, and then used as support to synthesize a series of rare earth elements (REE) modified Cr2O3 catalysts. The catalysts were systematically characterized and analyzed by XRD, N2 adsorption, HRTEM-EDS-MAPPING, XPS, TPO, H2-TPR, TPD and TPSR techniques. The structure-performance relationship of texture-structure of the catalysts, thermal stability and dispersion of active metals, and the performance for catalytic combustion of chlorobenzene (CB) were established. The results showed that there existed interaction between REE and Cr2O3, which induced the production of a certain amount of Cr6+ species on the catalyst surface that could enhance the catalytic performance of the catalysts. Among them, 10% CrNd(6:1)/KL-NY exhibited the highest catalytic activity and completely degrade CB at about 280 °C. Furthermore, 10%CrNd(6:1)/KL-NY represented high durability and good water-resistance for CB combustion during the long-term continuous test, indicating this catalyst deserved more attention and had great potential in industrial applications. Keywords Kaolin Rare earth Cr-Nd Chlorobenzene Catalytic combustion 1 Introduction Chlorinated volatile organic compounds (CVOCs), such as chlorobenzene (CB), are widely used in industry and mostly applied as solvents for degreasing processes, which are emitted into the atmosphere and regarded as highly toxic contaminants because of their strong mutagenic and carcinogenic activities, and they bring many negative environmental effects such as ozone depletion and global warming [1–4]. Thus, eliminating these organic waste gases with low concentration is of great importance. Among various terminal technologies, catalytic combustion is an effective mean due to its lower operating temperature and less secondary pollution [5–7]. Catalysts play an important role on CVOC catalytic elimination, and metal catalysts are widely applied. Metal catalysts usually contain two types: noble metal catalysts and non-noble metal catalysts. Noble metals usually show very excellent performance, but several weaknesses limit their widespread use, for example, high price and tendency to Cl poisoning [8–10]. Therefore, there are some very favorable factors for transition metal oxides catalysts, which resist deactivation to a larger extent and are cheaper. MnO2, CuO, Co3O4, V2O5 and Cr2O3 are often used in catalytic combustion reactions [11–15]. Among all the transition metal oxides, chromium-based catalysts are very effective for the catalytic oxidation of oxygen-containing compounds and especially chlorinated hydrocarbon [16–19] due to its variability of oxidation states and great resistance to poisoning. Rare earth elements (REE) have 4f orbitals without full electron occupancy and lanthanide contraction, which lead to their unique chemical property when they are used as promoter. As they are able to provide lattice oxygen, they have a unique ability to store and release oxygen, and if incorporate with transition metal oxides, it can improve the dispersion of active metals on the supports, increase redox properties of supported metal oxide catalysts, enhance thermal stability of materials and decrease the thermal sintering of the supports [8,20–23]. This leads to a signification improvement in catalyst performance. The existence of support is of great significance to the catalysts, which provides more choices for the catalysts. Support materials possess large specific surface areas and appropriate pore structures which are beneficial for the dispersion of the active components and improve catalytic thermal stability. The common supports include γ-Al2O3, MCM, TiO2, SBA and etc. [24–27]. Kaolin is one of the most versatile industrial minerals. Through acid or alkaline treatment, the specific surface area of kaolin can be increased and the pore structure can be improved. Therefore, modified kaolin can obtain excellent properties and is used extensively in many fields. As a cheap and economical raw material, Kaolin material can be used extensively to synthesize different types of molecular sieves, including ZSM-5 and NaY molecular sieve [28,29]. As an ideal carrier, Kaolin can be used to support metal oxides, and addition of REE into Kaolin can improve the thermal resistance and the dispersion of active components. There are rarely reports about REE modified Kaolin material-supported metal oxide catalysts for the catalytic combustion of CVOCs. Chlorobenzene (CB) is selected as a representative CVOCs to evaluate its oxidation process over the catalyst. In this paper, REE modified Kaolin material-supported Cr2O3 catalysts were synthesized, and their catalytic performance for CB combustion was explored. Some characterization techniques were applied to systematically analyze these catalysts, including XRD, N2 adsorption, HRTEM-EDS-MAPPING, XPS, TPO, H2-TPR, TPD and TPSR, and the probable reasons for their excellent catalytic activity were explained by these data. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Catalyst preparation Kaolin was first beaten into slurry, then the microspheres with particle sizes (20–110 μm) were obtained from the slurry through spray. The calcinated microspheres were hydrothermal crystallized under alkaline condition to form the composite catalytic material, which contained NaY-type molecular sieves growing on the inner and outer surface of the microspheres. After washing, filtration and drying, the composite material was calcinated at 500 °C for 2 h, so the kaolin-based NaY-type zeolite crystal (KL-NY) was formed. The supported catalysts were prepared through the equal impregnation method by choosing KL-NY as the support, the nitrate solution of Cr and REE (Y, Ce, La, Pr and Nd) as the precursors. Reaction overnight, then the solution was dried at 200 °C in the oven. After dried, the catalysts needed to be calcinated for 2 h at 500 °C, then some particles (40–60 meshes) were obtained through sieving, that were the Cr/KL-NY and CrREE/KL-NY catalysts. The total loading of Cr and REE on these catalysts was 10 wt.%. Based on the following study requirements, different Cr/Nd molar ratio catalysts were prepared. 2.2 Catalytic tests and durability test The catalytic performances of the catalysts (350 mg) for catalytic combustion of CB (1000 ppm in dry air) were conducted in WFS-3010 microreactor (Tianjin Xianquan, China). The space velocity was 20,000 h−1, and the reactive flow rate was 125 mL/min. The gas components in the outlet of the gas flow (the reactant, the any possible organic byproducts as well as the final products CO/CO2) were measured on-line via a Shimadzu GC-14C (operating condition: vaporizer temperature of 170 °C, column temperature of 120 °C), and the experimental data was collected and analyzed by N3000 GC data workstation (Zhejiang University, China). The other minority products were determined via gas chromatography mass spectrometry (GC–MS, QGA, HIDEN, UK). The durability test of the catalysts was also conducted under the same condition. 2.3 Material characterization KL-NY and the supported catalysts were characterized by many instruments. The crystal structure was characterized by X-ray diffraction (XRD, PANalytical EMPYREAN, Netherlands) [9]. The textural properties were detected by N2 adsorption (Micromeritics Company, USA) [9,14]. The morphology and chemical compositions were observed by high resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM, JEM-2100F, Japan) and energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS, OXFORD INCA, UK) [9,14,30]. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analysis was performed by a Thermo Scientific Escalab250Xi X-ray Photoelectron Spectrometer (USA). The C 1s of 284.6 eV was used as the internal reference to calibrate electron binding energies. 2.4 Temperature programmed reactions The temperature programmed oxidation (TPO) of the spent CrNd(6:1)/KL-NY catalyst (after durability test at 280 °C for 10 h, 1000 ppm CB, 20,000 h−1) was carried out in a U-type quartz tube. The catalyst was heated from 50 to 500 °C in 30 mL/min 20%O2/Ar flow at a heating rate of 10 °C/min, and CO and CO2 were monitored on-line by a mass spectrometer apparatus (QGA, HIDEN, UK). Additionally, the evolution of HCl and Cl2 adsorbed on the surface of the spent catalyst was also detected. H2 temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR) experiment was given in Ref. [14], CB temperature-programmed desorption (TPD) analysis and CB temperature-programmed surface reaction (TPSR) measurements were described in detail in our previous articles [9]. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalytic activity measurement Fig. 1 showed the catalytic activity of Cr/KL-NY was significantly improved after adding REE, especially for the catalyst containing Nd. The activity of CrREE/KL-NY with respect to REE was observed to follow the sequence: Nd > La > Ce > Pr > Y. As Nd modified Cr/KL-NY catalyst exhibited the highest catalytic activity, different Cr/Nd molar ratio for CrNd/KL-NY catalysts was the focus in this research. The results showed that the catalytic activity was the optimal when the Cr/Nd molar ratio was 6:1. As shown in Fig. 2 , T50 and T90 of CB conversion for CrNd(6:1)/KL-NY were about 230 and 260 °C, respectively. CB could be completely degraded at about 280 °C, which indicated that proper Cr/Nd molar ratio was also one of the critical factors determining the catalytic activity of CrNd/KL-NY catalysts. Different Nd concentrations had different effects on the activity of Cr/KL-NY catalyst in CB combustion. When Cr/Nd ratio was <6, the concentrations of the active species (Cr) decreased and too much Nd loading could override Cr2O3 active sites and reduced the surface area and pore volume of KL-NY, thus, the catalytic exhibited a relatively low activity. When Cr/Nd ratio was >6, decrease of the amount of NdOx results in the lack of oxygen vacancies, thus, the activity also deceased. Therefore, suitable Nd content was one of the important factors to optimize catalyst activity. In comparison with the property of noble metal catalysts and transition metal oxide catalysts in the study of Giraudon and Chiraz [31,32], CrNd(6:1)/KL-NY showed better catalytic activity in CB combustion, as shown in Table S1. From the detection results from GC–MS, in addition to H2O, CO2, and HCl, no byproducts were detected. The HCl produced in the process of CB combustion was further detected by the chlorine balance test. To analyze the chlorine balance, the waste gas was bubbled through a 0.0125 mol/L NaOH for 0.5 h. And the Cl− concentration was measured by the chlorine ion selective electrode. The calculated results showed that the Cl equilibrium reached about 85%, and the small amount of Cl loss may be due to pipeline or catalyst adsorption. 3.2 Durability test Durability test for CrNd(6:1)/KL-NY was shown in Fig. 3 . It was very stable during 100 h reaction, and the conversion of CB remained approximately 90% at 260 °C. There was no significant reduction in catalytic activity during the first continuous 10 h reaction in the presence of 100 ppm benzene, this was probably caused by competitive adsorption and oxidation on the active sites [21]. Then 3% water was introduced, the competitive adsorption became more intense, so the catalytic activity was further reduced. When benzene and water were removed, the activity returned to the original level. This indicated that coke and Cl species were taken away from the catalyst surface, when water was removed. The above results showed that CrNd(6:1)/KL-NY had potential industrial application prospects by reason of its excellent oxidative performance for catalytic combustion of both non-chlorinated and chlorinated VOCs. 3.3 XRD analysis The XRD patterns between 10° and 80° were shown in Fig. 4 . It was easy to observe that the diffraction peaks of Na2Al2Si4O12·8H2O appeared in the KL-NY, 10%Cr/KL-NY and 10%CrNd(6:1)/ KL-NY, indicating that there was little change in the framework of KL-NY after loading Cr and Nd. The diffraction peaks of Cr2O3 were detected in Cr/KL-NY, and the corresponding Cr2O3 and Nd2O3 peaks appeared in CrNd(6:1)/KL-NY. However, the intensity of peaks in CrNd(6:1)/KL-NY was significant weaker than that of Cr/KL-NY. It was because Cr2O3 and Nd2O3 active components were more dispersed on the surface of KL-NY. Considering the catalytic activity and the XRD results, it was not difficult to find that the catalytic activity was related to the dispersion of active components on KL-NY, the better dispersion, the better catalytic activity. 3.4 Analysis of specific surface area and pore structure N2 adsorption-desorption isotherm of the catalysts was shown in Fig. S1a. Obviously, the isotherm should belong to type Ⅵ, and these hysteresis loops should be the H3 type [8]. Based on these results, these porous materials were micro-mesopore composite structure. The adsorption capacity of Cr/KL-NY and CrNd/KL-NY was significantly reduced because their pore channels were blocked by some active components [33,34]. The detailed data of the catalysts were summarized in Table 1 . The S BET of KL-NY was 375 m2/g, and the corresponding V p was 0.367 cm3/g. After the addition of Cr and Nd, the S BET and V p of CrNd(6:1)/KL-NY decreased to 196 m2/g and 0.229 cm3/g, respectively, indicating that some Cr and Nd ions entered the pore channels. As shown in Fig. S1b, the pore size distribution was centered on 0.6 nm and 7.0 nm. There was no change in the pore size distribution of KL-NY after loading with Cr and Nd, but the intensity was slightly weakened, which indicated that KL-NY had a stable structure. Large amounts of pores in KL-NY support could facilitate good dispersion of active components and improved the contact between active sites and reactants, thus, their catalytic performances of gas-solid reactions could be greatly enhanced. 3.5 HRTEM-EDS-MAPPING The HRTEM images of KL-NY and CrNd(6:1)/KL-NY were shown in Fig. 5 . Fig. 5a showed that KL-NY had an orderly open framework and an evenly aligned two-dimensional layered structure. And the distance between layers was approximately 1.8 nm, therefore, there was a lot of pores in KL-NY. The existence of these pores could be conductive to production transport and increased the reaction rate. From Fig. 5b, the introduction of Cr and Nd didn’t destroy the layered structure but were uniformly distributed throughout the support and no aggregation occurred. It could also be clearly seen from the elemental mappings (Fig. S2), the Cr and Nd active components were successfully supported on the surface of KL-NY with highly dispersion. Similar results emerged from XRD and the N2 adsorption-desorption isotherm. The HRTEM images and elemental mappings clearly revealed that the stable layered structure and well-dispersed active components existed in KL-NY. Fig. 5c showed the EDS spectrum of CrNd(6:1)/KL-NY catalyst and the corresponding element contents were shown in Table 2 . Cr, Nd, Na, Al, Si, O and C elements were detected in this catalyst, and Cr/Nd molar ratio was almost 6:1 and the total loading of Cr and Nd on these catalysts was approximately 10 wt.%, indicating that Cr and Nd was successfully loaded on the KL-NY during the catalyst preparation process and the actual load of Cr and Nd was close to the theoretical value. 3.6 XPS characterization The oxidation states and content of the elements on the catalyst surface were detected by XPS, and the results were shown in Fig. 6 . The XPS spectra of Cr 2p were presented in Fig. 6a. For Cr/KL-NY, the binding energies of Cr 2p 1/2 were 586.0 and 587.9 eV, which were assigned to Cr (III) and Cr (VI), respectively. The binding energies of Cr 2p 3/2 were 576.7 and 579.6 eV, were related to Cr (III) and Cr (VI), respectively [35]. The XPS results confirmed the coexistence of two different Cr species (Cr3+ and Cr6+) on the surfaces of the catalyst. However, the binding energies of Cr 2p 1/2 and Cr 2p 3/2 exhibited positive shifts towards higher binding energy in the existence of REE, which might be associated with the electronic interaction between Cr and REE. There might be electron transfer between REE and Cr. Therefore, the addition of REE influenced the chemical state of Cr. It had been reported that Cr6+ on the surface of catalyst was much more active than Cr3+ for catalytic oxidation of CVOCs [36]. The ratio of Cr6+/(Cr3++ Cr6+) decreased as follows: CrNd (6:1)/KL-NY (0.53) > CrLa (6:1)/KL-NY (0.52) > CrPr (6:1)/KL-NY (0.49) > CrCe (6:1)/KL-NY (0.47) > CrY (6:1)/KL-NY (0.45) > Cr/KL-NY (0.42), indicating that the higher the content of Cr6+ species on the catalyst surface, the better catalytic performance of the catalysts for CB. In order to further investigate the influence of REE on the catalytic performance of the catalysts, the XPS spectra of O 1s were presented in Fig. 6b. The peak at 530.5 eV was attributed to lattice oxygen (OLatt) that from the oxidic lattice of Cr, Nd and REE. The peaks of surface active oxygen (Osur) species were located at 531.3 eV and 532.0 eV that were usually attributed to the presence of OH adsorbed groups. They played an important role in the oxidation process of CB. The peak at 532.7 eV was attributed to oxygen physically adsorbed on the KL-NY support surface. With the addition of REE, the binding energies of O 1s exhibited positive shift towards higher binding energy and the concentration of Osur had also increased, this result indicates that a change in structural arrangement and/or electronic structure has occurred due to the interaction between O and REE. Thus, the addition of REE induced changes in the O 1s chemical state and increases the amount of surface adsorbed active oxygen on the catalyst surface, which resulted in an improvement in the catalytic performance of the catalysts. The ratio of OSur/(OLatt + OSur) decreased in the order of CrNd (6:1)/KL-NY (0.75) > CrLa (6:1)/KL-NY (0.74) > CrPr (6:1)/KL-NY (0.73) > CrCe (6:1)/KL-NY (0.71) > CrY (6:1)/KL-NY (0.70) > Cr/KL-NY (0. 69). It could be concluded from the XPS spectra analysis of Cr 2p and O 1s that CrNd (6:1)/KL-NY had the highest catalytic performance for CB combustion. This conclusion was consistent with the activity evaluation experiments. Fig. 6c shown the XPS spectra of the Nd 3d core levels, the Nd 3d signal consisted of the 3d3/2 and 3d5/2 components. The 3d3/2 and 3d5/2 of Nd were observed at 1001.2 eV and 979.0 eV, respectively, which revealed that Nd ions existed in trivalent state on the surfaces of the catalyst. The interaction between Nd2O3 and Cr2O3 was beneficial for promoting the mobility of active oxygen species and improving the catalytic performances of the catalyst. For the Cr/KL-NY, adding Y, Ce, La, Pr and Nd all could promote the catalytic combustion from the result of XPS, however, Nd was the best. The XPS spectra of the Y 3d, Ce 3d, La 3d, Pr 3d had also been added in the Supplementary Material, as shown in Fig. S3. 3.7 TPO Fig. 7 presented TPO profiles of the spent CrNd(6:1)/KL-NY catalysts (Fresh for comparison), after the durability test at 280 °C for 10 h, to evaluate the formation of coke and the adsorption/desorption or transformation of HCl/Cl2 on the catalyst surface. MS signals of HCl and Cl2 of the spent catalyst, there was no apparent difference from those of the fresh catalyst, which implied that no adsorption of HCl occurred on the catalyst surface during the durability test. Meanwhile, no Cl2 signal was observed because no adsorption HCl could be oxidized to Cl2. Only weak MS signal of CO2 corresponding to the adsorption CO2 at low temperature, and no signal of CO was observed. These results confirmed that no coke was formed and no Cl species was adsorbed on the surface of the catalyst, and it was further verified that CrNd(6:1)/KL-NY had high efficiency in degrading CB. 3.8 H2-TPR H2-TPR profiles of the catalysts were shown in Fig. 8 . For Cr/KL-NY, there were two reduction peaks at 293 and 361 °C, which were the reduction peaks of Cr2O3 species with different particle sizes, respectively. The reduction peaks of CrNd(6:1)/KL-NY were shifted to lower temperature corresponding to 265 and 330 °C. So, the addition of Nd allowed Cr2O3 particles to be dispersed better on the surface of KL-NY, and decreased Cr2O3 particles size leaded to Cr2O3 easier to be reduced. Besides, introduction of Nd could improve the oxidation properties of Cr2O3, since the interaction between Nd2O3 and Cr2O3 increased mobility of oxygen species over this catalyst and existed a small amount of active Cr(VI) species in the catalyst [34]. Compared to other different Cr/Nd molar ratios catalysts, the reduction temperature of CrNd(6:1)/KL-NY was the lowest, which represented that it had the best catalytic oxidation performance, as shown in Fig. S4. This result indicated that the lower reduction temperature, the higher activity for catalytic combustion of CB. Therefore, loading Nd was beneficial to enhance oxidation property of Cr2O3 and promote catalytic activity of Cr based catalyst for CB catalytic combustion, especially for CrNd/KL-NY with the Cr/Nd molar ratio of 6. 3.9 Chlorobenzene adsorption/desorption analysis CB adsorption/desorption profiles of the catalysts were displayed in Fig. 9 . In Fig. 9a, CB adsorption capacity of Cr/KL-NY was larger than that of CrNd(6:1)/KL-NY. This was probably because larger pore volume was advantageous for CB adsorption. In Fig. 9b and c, CrNd(6:1)/KL-NY had a lower CB desorption temperature than that of Cr/KL-NY, which demonstrated that adsorbed CB was more easily desorbed for CrNd(6:1)/KL-NY. Besides, CB desorption temperature of CrNd(6:1)/KL-NY was closer to its CB combustion temperature, indicating that desorbed CB was more susceptible to catalytic oxidation. In a word, addition of Nd was beneficial for degradation of CB. 3.10 TPSR analysis Possible by-products and final products on the surface of catalyst were evaluated by in-situ TPSR technique, some useful information about actual oxidation process, oxidation properties under dynamic conditions and adsorption/desorption performance were obtained [9]. As shown in Fig. 10 a, in the range of 50–275 °C, the signal of CB in Cr/KL-NY appeared, while the signals of CO2, H2O and HCl were absent and only desorption of CB occurred at 208 °C. Compared with Cr/KL-NY, CrNd(6:1)/KL-NY had lower peak temperature of CB desorption at 182 °C. However, the signals of CO2, H2O and HCl appeared at about 175 °C in CrNd(6:1)/KL-NY, implying that CB desorption accompanied with CB combustion from Fig. 10b. With the increase of reaction temperature, the oxidation of CB was becoming increasingly evident as CO2, H2O and HCl were detected. Thus, CB adsorbed on the catalyst surface at low temperature was completely oxidized as the reaction temperature increased. Compared with Cr/KL-NY, CrNd(6:1)/KL-NY had lower CB completely oxidizing temperature. These results showed that the addition of Nd was beneficial for the catalytic combustion of CB, which was well in agreement with the order of catalyst activity measurement. 4 Conclusions In this article, there a high thermally stable support was obtained by in-situ crystallization named kaolin-based, NaY-type zeolite crystal (KL-NY), which possessed high specific surface area and large pore volume. Then Cr/KL-NY and CrREE/KL-NY catalysts were further prepared. Comparing with the catalytic activity of these catalysts in CB combustion reaction, CrNd(6:1)/KL-NY was the most outstanding. This catalyst could completely degrade CB at 280 °C. After finished a series of characterized and analyzed, the structure-activity relationship of the catalysts was confirmed. The introduction of activity components didn’t destroy the framework of KL-NY but was evenly distributed in the pores and on the surface of the support. The EDS and XPS spectra of 10%CrNd(6:1)/KL-NY catalyst showed that Cr, Nd and O were all present, indicating that active components were well loaded on the support. At the same time, the presence of Cr6+ and Nd3+ species on the catalyst surface was beneficial to improve the catalytic performance. In brief, the proper Nd content, highly dispersion and a certain amount higher oxidation state of active components on the catalyst surface as well as their strong interaction was the main factors to get highly active catalysts. 10%CrNd(6:1)/KL-NY showed a potential industrial application prospect to eliminate the CB pollution, due to its good performance in durability and the final products had no additional byproducts other than CO2, H2O and HCl. Acknowledgments This paper was supported by the National Natural Science Foundation of China (Grant No.21577094) and Zhejiang Public Welfare Technology Research Project (Grant No. LGG19B070003) and the Foundation of Science and Technology of the Shaoxing City (No. 2018C10019). The authors would like to acknowledge the financial support from Innovation Team of Huzhou South Taihu Elite Program. Moreover, we would also grateful to Zhejiang Da-Feng Automobile Technology Co., Ltd. for the related experiment and test. coredata.dc:description: In this paper, a kaolin-based NaY-type zeolite crystal (KL-NY) material with large specific surface area and pore volume was prepared through in-situ crystallization, and then used as support to synthesize a series of rare earth elements (REE) modified Cr2O3 catalysts. The catalysts were systematically characterized and analyzed by XRD, N2 adsorption, HRTEM-EDS-MAPPING, XPS, TPO, H2-TPR, TPD and TPSR techniques. The structure-performance relationship of texture-structure of the catalysts, thermal stability and dispersion of active metals, and the performance for catalytic combustion of chlorobenzene (CB) were established. The results showed that there existed interaction between REE and Cr2O3, which induced the production of a certain amount of Cr6+ species on the catalyst surface that could enhance the catalytic performance of the catalysts. Among them, 10% CrNd(6:1)/KL-NY exhibited the highest catalytic activity and completely degrade CB at about 280 °C. Furthermore, 10%CrNd(6:1)/KL-NY represented high durability and good water-resistance for CB combustion during the long-term continuous test, indicating this catalyst deserved more attention and had great potential in industrial applications.
coredata.dc:title: Rare earth modified kaolin-based Cr2O3 catalysts for catalytic combustion of chlorobenzene
